Our Mission

For over six years, the Corvid Tribunal Linguistic Preservation Society has worked tirelessly to document, teach, and protect Kraw'vethic — a language unlike any other on Earth. Born not from human need, but from the deliberative proceedings of an autonomous crow judicial system, Kraw'vethic represents something unprecedented: a grammar forged in case law, a vocabulary born from verdicts, a syntax shaped by centuries of corvid legal tradition.

We believe that every language matters — even ones created by birds who happen to run a court system out of a building that won't stay in one place. Especially those.

Documentation & Transcription

Our team of 14 full-time ornithological linguists works around the clock to transcribe new rulings as they're cawed from the bench. Each session of the Tribunal produces an average of 3.2 new words and 0.7 grammatical amendments, all of which must be catalogued before the building moves to the next timezone.

Education & Outreach

We offer free Kraw'vethic courses in 14 languages (15 if you count Kraw'vethic itself, which the Tribunal insists you must, per Ruling KV-2024-0331). Our mobile learning labs follow the building wherever it goes, though admittedly they sometimes lose it near mountain ranges.

Legal Recognition

We are actively petitioning 38 national governments to recognize Kraw'vethic as a protected minority language. So far, Liechtenstein has expressed “polite bewilderment,” which our legal team considers a promising first step.

Jazz Heritage Preservation

The Tribunal's constitutionally mandated live jazz band has been playing continuously since 2019. We provide instrument maintenance, musician housing (inside the moving building), and emotional support for the trumpet player, who has not slept in what he describes as “a while.”

The Kraw'vethic Language

Kraw'vethic (from the Old Corvid kraw meaning “law” and vethic meaning “the sound a gavel makes when dropped from a great height”) is a constructed language with an estimated 4,217 ratified words. Unlike Esperanto or Klingon, it was not designed by humans. Every element of Kraw'vethic — from its 47-phoneme inventory to its uniquely complex tense system that includes “the perpetual now of jazz” — was established through formal judicial proceedings.

Kraw'vethic Pronunciation English
Kraw'mesh vi'talok /kɹɔː.mɛʃ vi.tæ.lɒk/ Hello (lit. "The court acknowledges your presence")
Veth'na kraw'sik /vɛθ.nɑ kɹɔː.sɪk/ Thank you (lit. "Your testimony has been entered into the record")
Nok'threl vi'jazh /nɒk.θɹɛl vi.ʒæːʒ/ Where is the bathroom? (lit. "I petition for recess with urgency, the jazz is too loud")
Kraw'eth mok'thal si'ven /kɹɔː.ɛθ mɒk.θæl sɪ.vɛn/ Good morning (lit. "The gavel falls upon another sunrise and the building has moved again")
Threk'ven nok'si wail'fen /θɹɛk.vɛn nɒk.siː weɪl.fɛn/ I love you (lit. "I would defend you in Talon Court without fee")
Jazh'vek si'nol kraw'mesh /ʒæːʒ.vɛk sɪ.nɒl kɹɔː.mɛʃ/ Goodbye (lit. "May the saxophonist play you out gently")

Tense System: Kraw'vethic has nine tenses, three more than most human languages. In addition to past, present, and future, it includes kraw'ven (the legal precedent tense, used for events that happened but whose ruling is still binding), jazh'nol (the perpetual now of jazz, used exclusively during musical performances), and threk'mot (the architectural impermanent, for things that were true at a specific location but may not be anymore because the building moved).


Case System: Nouns decline based on the speaker's relationship to the Tribunal. There are four cases: Plaintive (for those bringing grievances), Defensive (for those answering charges), Judicial (reserved for sitting crow justices), and Melodic (used only by members of the jazz band, who have special constitutional linguistic privileges).


Word Order: Standard word order is Verdict-Subject-Object-Jazz Commentary. The final position, jazh'threk, is a mandatory musical annotation indicating the emotional timbre the speaker wishes the band to underscore their statement with. Omitting it is considered contempt of court.


Note on Gendered Language: Kraw'vethic has no gendered pronouns. Per Ruling KV-2021-0847 (“The Crows Do Not Care”), all beings are referred to by their role in the current proceeding. Outside of court, the generic pronoun krek is used for all entities, living or architectural.

Kraw'vethic English Legal Equivalent Notes
Kraw'eth mok'thral Objection sustained Accompanied by a specific three-note trumpet phrase, per constitutional mandate
Nok'ven si'threk Motion to relocate Filed automatically every time the building crosses a national border
Jazh'kraw meth'olven Musical evidence Admissible in all proceedings; the band plays the evidence live
Threk'nol vi'kraw si'wail Contempt of court Includes: talking during a solo, requesting the building stop, and mispronouncing any Kraw'vethic vowel
Mok'vel kraw'sik jazh'ven Case dismissed with jazz The preferred resolution; the band plays the defendant's chosen song as they leave

In the Press

Selected coverage from human media outlets attempting to understand what we do

The New York Times — Science

“A Murder of Crows Created a Language. Then They Built a Legal System. Then Their Building Started Moving.”

“What began as a curious behavioral study at the University of Helsinki has evolved into something that linguists, ornithologists, and constitutional scholars are struggling to categorize. The Corvid Tribunal — a self-organized judicial body comprising an estimated 891 crows — has over six years developed a functional constructed language with consistent phonology, morphology, and a remarkably sophisticated tense system. Perhaps more bewildering is the fact that the physical structure housing the Tribunal appears to be in constant, slow motion across the Eurasian continent, a phenomenon that no one, including the nonprofit tasked with preserving the language, can explain.”

March 14, 2025
Wired

“Inside the Jazz Band That Can Never Stop Playing”

“Marcus Oyelaran has been the lead saxophonist of the Tribunal's constitutionally mandated jazz ensemble for three years. He sleeps in shifts. He eats while playing sustained notes. His calluses have calluses. ‘The crows were very clear in Ruling KV-2022-1104,’ he tells me, still playing a legato run over our conversation. ‘The music must not stop. It is, and I am quoting directly from the bench here, the sonic architecture upon which all jurisprudence rests.’ When I ask if he's considered quitting, he looks at me with an expression I can only describe as terrified reverence. ‘You don't quit the Tribunal,’ he says. ‘The Tribunal quits you. And then the building leaves.’”

January 8, 2025
The Economist

“The Migratory Courthouse: Property Law Has No Answer for This”

“The CTLPS headquarters — a converted five-story brutalist office building that once housed a Finnish telecommunications company — has crossed 63 national borders since 2019, paying no customs duties, violating no immigration laws (the crows hold no passports), and accruing property taxes in approximately zero jurisdictions, as it is never in one place long enough to be assessed. The building travels at an average speed of 3.2 kilometers per hour, roughly the pace of a brisk walk, which has made it the subject of 14 separate international property law dissertations and one truly bewildered Interpol memo.”

November 22, 2024
NPR — All Things Considered

“Learning Kraw'vethic: When Your Language Teacher Is a Bird and Your Classroom Won't Stop Moving”

“I arrived at the CTLPS headquarters at 9 AM in what was then suburban Bucharest. By lunch, we were somewhere in Moldova. The class continued uninterrupted. Our instructor — a human named Petra, who has a PhD in comparative linguistics and a notably unhealthy relationship with corvid case law — taught us the basics while a jazz trio played Coltrane in the next room. ‘The perpetual jazz is actually helpful for learning,’ Petra insisted, shouting over a drum solo. ‘Kraw'vethic has a musical tense. You literally cannot conjugate correctly without a live rhythm section.’”

September 3, 2024

Volunteer With Us

We need dedicated humans willing to follow a moving building across continents while documenting an avian legal language over a live jazz soundtrack. Previous experience optional. Stamina mandatory. Here are our current openings:

Field Transcriptionist

Attend live Tribunal sessions and transcribe rulings in real-time. Must be comfortable working in a building that averages 3.2 km/h and does not have a fixed mailing address. Headphones not permitted (the jazz is constitutionally protected).

Full-time • Nomadic

Building Location Tracker

Maintain our real-time GPS coordinates and update local authorities when the building enters their jurisdiction. Requires diplomatic tact, as many municipalities have questions. We do not have answers.

Part-time • Remote (ironically)

Jazz Band Roadie

Maintain instruments, manage the band's schedule (they do not stop playing, so "schedule" is generous), and ensure the piano stays tuned despite constant seismic movement. Must be able to lift 40 kg while the floor is subtly moving northeast.

Full-time • On-building

Kraw'vethic Community Teacher

Lead free language classes in communities the building passes through. The building typically stays in one metropolitan area for 2-5 days, so lesson plans should be modular. A background in linguistics, education, or corvid law is preferred.

Part-time • Various locations

Crow Liaison Officer

Serve as the primary point of communication between the 891 sitting justices and the human staff. Must have completed Kraw'vethic Level II certification. Must not be afraid of birds. Must be willing to accept that the birds are in charge.

Full-time • On-building

Grant Writer

Apply for funding from foundations, governments, and confused philanthropists. Experience writing grant proposals that include the phrase "moving building" and "avian judiciary" with a straight face is essential. Our last grant writer quit after trying to explain us to the MacArthur Foundation.

Contract • Remote

Our Team

The humans (and others) keeping Kraw'vethic alive

PL
Dr. Petra Lähteenmäki
Executive Director
Former professor of endangered languages at the University of Helsinki. Discovered the Tribunal in 2018 while studying corvid vocalizations. Has not returned to academia. Speaks fluent Kraw'vethic and describes the experience as “like being gently cross-examined by extremely musical birds.”
MO
Marcus Oyelaran
Head of Jazz Operations
Lead saxophonist and director of the constitutionally mandated jazz ensemble. Joined in 2022 after the previous saxophonist was “released by the bench.” Holds a master's from Berklee. Has played continuously for 1,127 days. His calluses have been the subject of a medical journal article.
KS
Justice Krek'moth Si'valen
Board Member (Corvid Representative)
Senior associate justice on the Third Talon Circuit. Has authored over 900 opinions, 47 of which established new vocabulary. Considered the Tribunal's foremost expert on the intersection of property law and building movement. Once issued a 14-hour ruling entirely in the Melodic case.
HC
Hector Castañeda-Ruiz
Director of Building Logistics
Former logistics coordinator for Médecins Sans Frontières. Joined the CTLPS because “it was the most challenging logistics problem I'd ever heard of.” Responsible for notifying governments when the building enters their territory. Maintains a spreadsheet of 63 countries' confused diplomatic responses.

Frequently Asked Questions

We understand this question. We get it a lot, usually from immigration officials. Yes, the Corvid Tribunal is a real, autonomous judicial body comprising approximately 891 crows. Yes, they created a language through formal proceedings. Yes, the building moves. Yes, there is always live jazz. We are a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit. Our tax returns are publicly available and include a line item for “saxophone reeds (emergency).”

We don't know. Our structural engineers have confirmed that the building has no wheels, no tracks, no engines, and no discernible means of locomotion. It simply moves. The crows seem unbothered by this. When asked directly (via certified Kraw'vethic interpreter), Chief Justice Threk'volen Nok'mesh replied: “The court goes where justice requires. Also the bassist prefers a temperate climate.” We have submitted 11 research proposals to study the phenomenon. All have been rejected by funding bodies who assume we are joking.

No. Per Kraw'vethic Civic Code §14.7, the jazz is constitutionally mandated and must continue at all times. The ensemble works in shifts. There are currently 11 musicians rotating through the schedule. The music serves a dual constitutional function: it provides the rhythmic foundation for the Melodic grammatical case, and it is — according to Ruling KV-2023-0519 — “the heartbeat of jurisprudence.” The one time the music accidentally stopped (a power outage in rural Slovakia, 2021), all court proceedings were retroactively declared a mistrial and the crows refused to reconvene until a backup generator was installed. We now have four backup generators.

Yes, but you'll need to find it first. Our real-time location tracker (updated every 15 minutes) is available on our website. We recommend checking it frequently, as the building's trajectory is unpredictable. Once you locate it, simply walk alongside the building at approximately 3.2 km/h and enter through the main door (which faces whichever direction the building was originally oriented when it was a Finnish telecom office, so currently north-northeast). Visitor hours are 9 AM to 5 PM local time. Please note that “local time” changes constantly.

That depends on your definition of “hard.” The phoneme inventory (47 distinct sounds, 12 of which are described as “percussive” and require tongue positions that human anatomy struggles with) can be challenging. The nine-tense system requires a conceptual leap, particularly the Architectural Impermanent tense, which requires the speaker to know the building's current GPS coordinates. And the mandatory jazz commentary at the end of every sentence does require some basic musical literacy. That said, our most advanced human student, Tomás Ferreira, achieved fluency in approximately 26 months. He describes the experience as “transformative” and “not compatible with having a fixed address.”

New vocabulary is established exclusively through formal judicial proceedings. When the Tribunal encounters a concept for which no Kraw'vethic word exists, a case is brought before the bench. Both sides present arguments (musically accompanied, per constitutional requirement). The justices deliberate, typically for 3-7 hours, and issue a ruling that includes the new word, its phonological structure, its grammatical class, and a 2-4 page legal opinion explaining the etymology. Recent additions include tek'nol'veth (smartphone — lit. “the glowing rectangle of distraction, which the court views with suspicion”) and kraw'Brexit (a word for a political decision that the Tribunal ruled “phonologically absurd in any language”).

Our Director of Building Logistics, Hector Castañeda-Ruiz, notifies the relevant government approximately 48 hours in advance (when the trajectory is predictable, which is about 60% of the time). Responses vary. The Czech Republic has issued us a standing transit visa for a building, which their own legal team admits has no precedent. Turkey asked us to stop. We explained that we don't control the building. They asked us who does. We said the crows. The conversation ended shortly thereafter. Switzerland, notably, has asked us to come back. They found the jazz “pleasant” and the Tribunal's property law opinions “surprisingly well-reasoned.”
